name: tris(3-methoxyphenyl)phosphine
Reason: 3-Methoxyphenyl groups, when connected to a phosphine base, significantly increase the melting point due to the introduction of a rigid, planar structure with potential hydrogen bonding. Each methoxy group introduces additional molecular weight and van der Waals forces, raising the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The phosphine base itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. The methoxy groups also increase the melting point due to the additional molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +20 degrees Celsius. The presence of three methoxyphenyl groups can significantly increase the melting point due to the introduction of a rigid, planar structure with potential hydrogen bonding. Each methoxy group introduces additional molecular weight and van der Waals forces, raising the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius.
